title: Corporate
descriptions:
Corporate (2006) is a Hindi-language drama that dissects the ruthless world of big business through the rivalry between two powerful Indian conglomerates. At the center is Nishigandha “Nishi” Dasgupta, a sharp, ambitious executive who serves as the rising star and trusted lieutenant of Dharmesh Marwah, the charismatic head of the Marwah Group of Industries. Their primary competitor is the sinister, politically connected Sehgal Group, led by the calculating Vinay Sehgal. Both groups vie for dominance in the booming FMCG and beverages sector, where a new soft drink becomes the battleground for market share, political favor, and personal survival.

Nishi orchestrates aggressive marketing tactics and strategic alliances to ensure Marwah’s product launch succeeds. As the race intensifies, corporate espionage and media manipulation enter the fray. A crucial breakthrough seems to arrive when Marwah’s team discovers a way to slash costs and ramp up production. But internal compromises made to meet deadlines and undercut the competition begin to have dire consequences. When allegations surface that the drink contains harmful contaminants, the scandal explodes, drawing public outrage, government scrutiny, and a vicious blame game.

To contain the fallout and protect top brass, Marwah’s legal and PR machinery works overtime to craft a narrative that isolates responsibility. Nishi, who had executed orders with unwavering loyalty and believed in the company’s vision, finds herself pushed into the line of fire. Her romantic relationship with Ritesh, an idealistic bureaucrat, complicates matters further as he struggles between personal loyalty and professional ethics.

As investigations intensify, backroom deals unfold between corporate leaders and politicians, revealing how power brokers manipulate regulations and media cycles. The competing conglomerates exploit the scandal to weaken each other, and the truth becomes secondary to damage control. Nishi is encouraged—then pressured—to take the fall for decisions made above her pay grade. Despite her talent and dedication, she learns the hard limits of merit in a system designed to shield the powerful.

Corporate ultimately charts Nishi’s disillusionment as she confronts the moral cost of ambition and the stark asymmetry of accountability. In a devastating climax, she accepts blame to save the company’s reputation and protect her superiors, only to realize she has been abandoned. The film ends on a sobering note: while stock prices stabilize and boardrooms move on, the individual who carried out orders bears life-altering consequences. Through Nishi’s arc, the movie paints an unflinching portrait of modern capitalism in India—where profits are prioritized, ethics are negotiable, and human lives are expendable in the pursuit of market dominance.

With its taut pacing and grounded performances, Corporate exposes the mechanisms of influence—lobbying, media spin, regulatory capture—and shows how the veneer of sleek professionalism masks a cutthroat ecosystem. It’s a cautionary tale about complicity, the fragility of professional loyalty, and the human cost hidden behind glossy brand campaigns.
